section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with an activity, and introduce vocabulary (push, pull).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What did Bird need to do to build her nest?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing opportunities for measurement.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.”

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Subitize the number of items in a group up to five.
Identify and solve problems.
Ask and answer questions about a text.
Understand and use academic language.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Set up and explain a 5-frame.
Model using a 5-frame to count.
Have children use the 5-frame to get from numbers zero to five total sticks.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Was anything being built in the book? Describe it.
Pretend to gather objects for a nest like Bird.
How many worms will you put out for Bird to eat?
Write a story or real information about a bird.
Can you make a bird’s nest?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of bird?
Use blocks and other objects to build a bird’s nest. Why did you use those objects to build the bird’s nest?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder identify and solve problems and introduce vocabulary (solve, problem).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Bird Builds a Nest.
Read closely to identify problems and their solutions and focus on operations.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.”

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Subitize the number of items in a group up to five.
Identify and solve problems.
Ask and answer questions about a text.
Understand and use academic language.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Explain that 5-frames can be used to understand and solve math problems.
Guide children to use the 5-frame to add numbers of materials from the book.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Does anyone in your book have a problem? What is it?
Can you move like a bird?
Can you show three on a 5-frame? What about one more?
Have you ever had a problem? What did you do to solve it?
Can you make or draw a bird in a nest?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word nest?
Did you make a plan for what you are building? Have you had any problems while you are working? How will you try to solve them?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to discuss measurement, engage children a game, and introduce vocabulary (heavy, light).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Bird Builds a Nest and asking the guiding question, What makes Bird’s nest cozy?
Read interactively for a closer understanding of the story and weight.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.”

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Subitize the number of items in a group up to five.
Identify and solve problems.
Ask and answer questions about a text.
Try to use new words and grammar.
State multiple ideas in a single sentence.
Understand and use academic language.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use counters to represent pillows.
Guide children to use the 5-frame to subitize numbers between one and five.
Challenge children to display numbers in a 5-frame.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Is there anything in your book that is heavy? Is there anything light?
Can you pretend to carry something really heavy?
Which items feel heavy? Which items feel light?
Can you write about a problem you’ve had? How did you solve it?
What materials would you use to make something heavy?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of heavy? Can you write this letter?
How could you make what you are building heavier? How could you make it lighter?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Bird Builds a Nest by Martin Jenkins, illustrated by Richard Jones. Text copyright © 2018 by Martin Jenkins. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Richard Jones. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © An Nguyen/Shutterstock.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: The Three Little Rabbits

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to get children excited to read about building on the Big Chart of Big Ideas and introduce vocabulary words (sticks, straw).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts The Three Little Rabbits and Bird Builds a Nest.
Read interactively and connect to measurement by discussing whether different building materials are heavy or light.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.”

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Subitize the number of items in a group up to five.
Identify and solve problems.
Ask and answer questions about a text.
Understand and use academic language.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use counters on a 5-frame to represent bags of materials.
Have children use 5-frames to determine how many bags are needed to have five bags in all.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Does anyone in your book have a problem? How did they solve it?
Pretend to be building a house. What materials are you using?
What could you count with a 5-frame?
What materials would you use to build a house? Why?
Can you draw a strong house? What does it look like?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of rabbit? What sound do you hear at the end of rabbit?
Which heavy materials could you use to build a strong house?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Bird Builds a Nest by Martin Jenkins, illustrated by Richard Jones. Text copyright © 2018 by Martin Jenkins. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Richard Jones. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: crayons (Svitlana Kataieva), tape (An Nguyen).

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to connect the book to scientific thinking, engage children with a song, and review vocabulary (heavy, light).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, Why did Bird build a nest?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on measurement.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.”

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Identify and solve problems.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Ask and answer questions about a text.
Try to use new words and grammar; State multiple ideas in a single sentence.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What materials would you use to build a house? What would your house be like?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s responses to display next week.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Did you like this book? Would you tell a friend to read it? Why?
Can you pretend to build a house? What is it made of?
How can you use a 5-frame to show four?
Write a story about an animal building a home.
Can you draw a cozy home? Show me the parts that make it cozy.
Think about the words stick and straw. What sound do you hear at the beginning of these words? What letters make that sound?
Which materials in this center would you use to build a house? Why did you pick those?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Bird Builds a Nest by Martin Jenkins, illustrated by Richard Jones. Text copyright © 2018 by Martin Jenkins. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Richard Jones. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from one to five.
Using concrete objects, create pictorial models and share a verbal word problem for adding up to five objects.
Informally recognize and compare weights of objects or people.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss position and motion of objects.
Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from 1–5.
Using concrete objects, create pictorial models and share a word problem for adding up to 5 objects.
Informally recognize and compare weights of objects or people.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000–4,000 words.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss motion of objects.
Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from 1–5.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set.
Informally recognize and compare weights of objects or people.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words.
Combine more than one idea using complex sentences.
Attempt to use new vocabulary and grammar in speech.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss motion of objects.
Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from one to five.
Using concrete objects, create pictorial models and share a verbal word problem for adding up to five objects.
Informally recognize and compare weights of objects or people.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss position and motion of objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set.
Informally recognize and compare weights of objects or people.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss position and motion of objects.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words.
Combine more than one idea using complex sentences.
Attempt to use new vocabulary and grammar in speech.
